**What are the different types of reasoning?**
The six types of reasoning skills are: Deductive, Inductive, Abductive, Casual, Comparative, and Analogical.
**Which type of reasoning is used when?**
When used to logically reason through the world, deductive reasoning can also be classified as direct inference, which involves starting with a set of true propositions (hypotheses) and inferring their conclusion from known relationships contained in them.
**What is argument in reasoning?**
Arguments are the type of writing in which a thesis statement is the main focus and the supporting information is based on previous research written by other writers and other supporting information. Most of the arguments are written in essays.
**What is an assumption example?**
“You are an excellent programmer” is an assumption because it is something that you think is true, although you cannot prove it is true.
**What is a logical fallacy?**
Logical fallacies are mistakes in logic that create invalid arguments. Logical fallacies are commonly included among the list of forms of argumentation errors that are associated with fallacies. Fallacies are errors in reasoning and argumentation.
**What are the types of reasoning?**
In general, there are two types of reasoning: deductive reasoning and inductive reasoning. The difference between these two types of reasoning is their purpose. Inductive reasoning is used to “collect patterns of general behavior or knowledge,” whereas deductive reasoning is used to “reach generalizations from specific outcomes.”

## Chapter 3: Programming Python
Here is an outline for building functions:

Write a test that calls the function and displays the results.
Write what the function should do.
Start with the test then fill in the rest of the function.
Here is an outline for adding to your functions:

Ask yourself if you want to add anything from the first function.
Ask yourself if the function needs any new information you haven’t accounted for yet.
Ask yourself if there is something you can ask the original function to do for you.
Make sure the test still passes.
Write the changes into the function.
There are generally 2 ways to solve problems. You can either just start writing code and add to it, or you can start with a plan. While it’s great to be intuitive when you’re programming, sometimes it helps to have a strategy in order to make sure you don’t lose your way. It’s best to test your code as often as possible, so that if you mess something up, you’ll find out sooner rather than later. It takes a little more upfront work, but it’ll give you confidence that you know what your code is doing! If you need help brainstorming how to write code, ask your friends, your instructor, or use an online forum. Don't worry, you’ll be writing code by the end of the quarter, and once you have a sense of programming, it will become second nature.


## Chapter 4: Lists
There are a few parts to creating a program, but if you get stuck at any point, you can always come here by reading the relevant section in your textbook. The steps we did for the functions chapter still apply here, so please review that chapter and make sure you understand the process.

You can also create a new file to test your functions separately from your program. Use comments to outline what your functions do. You may want to ask how and where to begin your program.

Ask the user what game they like at each step, then add those choices to a list as strings. Once you have 4 items in the list, display the list.
Ask the user to choose a game from the list, then display that game.
Ask the user to choose the game they would like to remove from the list. Make it so that the user can input either the exact name of the game, or any letter they want from the game's name (case doesn’t matter). If they input the game by name, remove it from the list. If they input part of the game’s name, remove the first instance of the game they chose, no matter how many letters they choose from the game name.
Ask the user to choose the game they think is on the list, then use in and not in to display whether their choice is or is not on the list.
Ask the user to enter their favorite game (this can be the same game they are on the list), then remove it from the list. If the game they chose to remove is already not on the list, print a message saying so to the user.
Ask the user a number (1-4). Then print their choice as a number based on index position in the list. If the user enters something invalid, print a message saying so to the user.


## Chapter 5: Loops

## Program: Functions, Arguments, and Loops

Use a while loop and input() to have the user enter as many numbers as they want (up to the user) and then display the sum of all those numbers using a function.
Use a while loop (not a range) and input() to ask users their name as often as they enter one into the program. After 3 names are entered, the program will display how many names have been entered. When the user leaves their name blank, have the program display all of the names entered.
Use range to count from 1 to 10 and use if statements to display Fizz if divisible by 3, Buzz if divisible by 5, FizzBuzz if divisible by both three and five.

## Program: More Games Functions and Loops

Have friends play a game where the program randomly chooses a game, and then the user will guess what the game is. The program will tell the user what letters are in the game name, and the user will guess the game. If the user enters a letter that’s in the game, it will be marked as guessed using a ‘*’, and the user will see all of the correct letters being guessed. If they enter a letter that’s not in the game, it will be marked as an incorrect letter, and they will see it under the letters correctly guessed. If the user guesses the whole name correctly, they get a congratulatory message. If they run out of guesses, they lose. To give the user feedback and let them know where they are, the user can press enter once to see letters they haven’t guessed yet, or press enter twice to see the total letters in the puzzle.

## 5.20: Deductive Reasoning

A study shows that the students who study math are more likely to be good students in general.

Let's start with the statement above, and see if we can't show that "if the students study math then they are good students in general" is a valid conclusion.

From the first statement, we can see that if the students study math then they are math students--this is an implicit assertion, because everyone knows that all math students are good students.

Next, we should try to work up to the conclusion. From this reasoning, we can see that if the students are math students, then they are good students--this is implicit, because all math students are good students.

Next, we work backward using modus ponens. From the assumption that they are good students, we can conclude that they are good students in general--this is implicit, since everyone knows that they, or those who are good students, are good students in general.

Let's apply this to a few sample "proofs" and work it from both directions to see what conclusions we might be able to draw:

A: If it snows, I stay in.
B: It snowed, and I stayed in.

A: If it rains, I don't leave my house.
B: It rained, and I stayed in.

A: If it rains today, I don't leave my house.
B: If it rains today, then I will stay in.

A: If it rains today, then I will stay in.
B: I stayed in.

instruction: A farmer has three types of animals: cows, sheep and chickens. Each animal produces a different amount of milk, wool and eggs. A cow produces 10 liters of milk, 0 kg of wool and 0 eggs per day, a sheep produces 1 liter of milk, 2 kg of wool and 0 eggs per day, and a chicken produces 0.5 liters of milk, 0 kg of wool and 1 egg per day. The farmer wants to have a total of 100 animals that produce at least 100 liters of milk, 100 kg of wool and 100 eggs per day. How many cows, sheep and chickens should the farmer have? Explain your reasoning.
combined_input: A farmer has three types of animals: cows, sheep and chickens. Each animal produces a different amount of milk, wool and eggs. A cow produces 10 liters of milk, 0 kg of wool and 0 eggs per day, a sheep produces 1 liter of milk, 2 kg of wool and 0 eggs per day, and a chicken produces 0.5 liters of milk, 0 kg of wool and 1 egg per day. The farmer wants to have a total of 100 animals that produce at least 100 liters of milk, 100 kg of wool and 100 eggs per day. How many cows, sheep and chickens should the farmer have? Explain your reasoning. In nutrientOPT managerial
generated_output: problem, the firm's goal is to produce the desired mix of products at the lowest combination of inputs. This is also called input mix problem. Input mix problem will be helpful in determining the relative importance of different elements in formulating policy. Input mix also represents a way of measuring how well the firm is using its scarce resources. It also helps in determining how best the input could be allocated, the optimum input mix would correspond to that combination of inputs which give maximum profits. The production function is used to evaluate or predict the production levels of various products. Product mix refers to the mix of products the firm produces. For example, the firm might decide to switch from producing only a single type of product to producing two or three related products, as in Coke producing soft drinks and the sugar used as part of the sugar cane used for production. As the number of products increases, the input mix, which has to be provided to each product, has to provide larger amounts of each input. In other words, as firms increase their product offerings, they use more capital and labour to produce each unit of output. 3. What are factors that affect production capacity? Explain production function. The relationship between the levels of inputs used and the levels of output produced is captured in a production function. The firm's technology is captured in the technology for producing its final output. In other words the technology for a production process captures all of the knowledge and skills that a firm employs to transform inputs into outputs. 4. Explain types of production function. The production function represents the firm's output of a good (often the firm's final product) as a function of its inputs, and allows the firm to determine which quantities of inputs it uses to produce a given quantity of output. The production function is usually written in symbolic form as: q = f(k, l, m) where q is the output (quantities of inputs are denoted by subscript variable such as k,l,m,.... and superscript variable such as f represent technology), k is the level of capital, l is the quantity of labour input, m is the quantity of other inputs (such as raw materials) and f is the technology for producing q given inputs  Short-run production function (a production function that is fixed in the short run and depends upon the quantities of variable inputs employed in the short run)  Long-run production function (a production function that moves the firm towards its most productive use of its inputs. 5. Write the short run production function for two input technology for the firm. 6. Write the production function for a firm which uses two inputs labour and machine hours for the output of final product. 7. State two important characteristics of production function. 8. What are key elements of production function? 9. State how many factors of production are necessary to identify the technology of production. 10. Differentiate production function from cost function using examples. 6. What is the difference between isoquant and isocost function? The two most common functions of production are Isoquants and Iso-costs. An isoquant represents a locus of all points on the production surface that produce the same output. An isocost relates all the points on a production frontier that cost the same. For illustration the isoquant curve and isocost curve are represented in the below diagram. 7. Write the formula for iso-quants and isocosts. 8. Define the marginal productivity of a factor in production. Explain the law of diminishing marginal productivity in a tabular form? 9. What is economic efficiency is production? Discuss the meaning of technical efficiency? 10. With the help of diagram explain Law of diminishing returns. A production, which refers to the inputs supplied and output realized; can be of two types:  Short run production − which requires certain fixed factor inputs for productively employing other variable inputs.  Long run production − which could employ both fixed and variable inputs to produce the same or different levels of output. In long run production any variable factors can be adjusted efficiently if it is desirable to employ different levels of factor inputs. Short run production is important as it explains production in limited time period as a firm or industry can be closed for some time period for technical or mechanical reasons. Since fixed factors remain constant, the only choice made available to the firms is to employ or increase variable factors. So, it is very important to understand how to use variable factors efficiently. Short and long run production are defined by the number of variable factors that are considered to be variable. Production at constant scale is a special case of production whereby the productivities of all variable inputs are assumed to be fixed and constant at the equilibrium production level. It will not necessarily imply the existence of constant returns to scale. For example, the production of some raw materials may not be subject to diminishing returns but the production of its product may be reduced in output. Since the law of returns to scale defines the functional relation between output and the variable inputs, the law of returns to scale would be applicable only if it is a common feature to all the industries studied in a hypothetical case. The analysis has to be carried out sector by sector and industry by industry basis to draw an inference regarding commonality of return to scale all the different sectors or industries. Further on analysing commonality may provide us an idea of functional relationship between output and variable inputs at the macro level. As under the following assumptions the relationship between output and factor input is given by: Y=f(K,L) Where, Y= Dependent Variable K denotes capital. L represents Labour. Hence, by definition of production function Y is functionally related to K and L through. A particular functional form of the production function will generally depend on the characteristics of the product and on the factors that may affect production. There are many functional form available to represent production which includes Cobb-Douglas Production function, Log-linear and Linear Production function. 4. What are the different types of production function and explain them? 5. What is production function? A production function shows the relationship between the quantities of inputs used and the quantity of output produced. A production function relates inputs to output (the firm's profit or loss depends not just on the quantity of output produced but on each and every combination of inputs required, since it is the total profit or loss that the firm is trying to maximise). The production function is a form of mathematical function that shows the relationship between inputs and outputs. The production function is one of the two most important elements of cost theory. It is a key concept when attempting to explain the relationship between production inputs and outputs of a firm. 6. Define marginal products and explain the law of diminishing returns. In short-run production the firm uses a fixed amount of capital and varying quantity of labour and varying quantity of labour output is referred to as marginal product of labour. Thus we can define the following measures: 11. State the importance of longandshortrunproductionanalysis. The production of any firm can be classified into two types: Short and long run. In short run production a firm uses a fixed factor i.e. capital and variable factor i.e. labour. Whereas, In long run production all factors can be varied to produce output. In short run production we cannot use more variable factor because of fixed factor. For example, short run production of machine with less capital. The firms can increase output in short run by hiring more workers. The changes in quantity of variable factors i.e. labour are continuous, so this type of production analysis is called. Whereas in long run we can vary all factors. In this type of production the law of returns to scale holds. Here, the firm can not use only one factor because the whole process will not work. 1\. Write short and long run of production. Explain the law of returns to scale with graph. 8.1 SHORT-RUN PRODUCTION PROBLEMS A firm operates in an environment of a large number of potential competitors and substitutes. Therefore, a firm must plan its operations so as to maximize profits. Profit maximization is not a decision to be made by the individual firm alone, but by the industry as a whole. One of the goals of production is to find what is the quantity of output given a set of inputs, and this goal can be accomplished without considering the competition. However, if the set of competitors expands, then firms should not just look at the quantity of output alone, but also compare it with the quantity supplied by its competitors. This is because the competitive environment allows firms to make certain assumptions such as: (i) each competitive firm produces the same good as others and (ii) there is perfect substitutability amongst the firms. A firm must make a planning decision based on the competitive assumption to ensure that it could meet its profit maximization goals. Short-run production refers to the determination of the optimal quantity of output using a fixed input. This is important because most inputs are fixed in the short run. Therefore, only change in production is due to changes in variable inputs. For instance, in the case of electricity generation, one can have a particular amount of electricity generated using certain machines without altering machine sizes. The input factors include not only the actual machines, but also the inputs associated with each machine such as workers, machinery, plant, machinery, production facilities etc. Let's look at them with the help of diagram shown below: 8.2 LONG-RUN PRODUCTION PROBLEMS In the long run, a firm can increase its usage of inputs at any time or at any point in time. So we can say that it uses a fixed size of each input and any quantity of other inputs. In long run, the output increases with the increase in the inputs and inputs increase but the cost does not change. Long-Run Technology Long-run technology refers to production process which will maximize the level of output with respect to inputs, and which will change continuously as the business environment changes. In long run, a firm can expand its operation at will given that it is feasible. It assumes that at any point in time, the firm would be using some optimal combination of productive inputs to yield highest desirable output. Let us take the example of electricity generation. At any point in time all available electricity is generated using all available machines of various sizes. Thus long-run refers to the optimal combination of inputs. 1\. What are factors involved production function and long and short run and economic efficiency? 2. What is production function and explain the law of diminishing returns? 3. Explain the long and short run production problems. 19.2 SHORT-RUN PRODUCTION PROBLEMS A firm operates in an environment of a large number of potential competitors and substitutes. Therefore, a firm must plan its operations so as to maximize profits. Profit maximization is not a decision to be made by the individual firm alone, but by the industry as a whole. One of the goals of production is to find what is the quantity of output given a set of inputs. This goal can be accomplished without considering the competition. However, if the set of competitors expands, then firms should not just look at the quantity of output alone, but also compare it with the quantity supplied by its competitors. This is because the competitive environment allows firms to make certain assumptions such as: (i) each competitive firm produces the same good as others and (ii) there is perfect substitutability amongst the firms. A firm must make a planning decision based on the competitive assumption to ensure that it could meet its profit maximization goals. Short-run production refers to the determination of the optimal quantity of output using a fixed input. This is important because most inputs are fixed in the short run. Therefore, only change in production is due to changes in variable inputs. For instance, in the case of electricity generation, one can have a particular amount of electricity generated using certain machines without altering machine sizes. The input factors include not only the actual machines, but also the inputs associated with each machine such as workers, machinery, plant, machinery, production facilities etc. Let's look at them with the help of diagram shown below: 8.2 LONG-RUN PRODUCTION PROBLEMS This section focuses on Long-run production problems. As long as a firm could keep its short-run production processes, it is a simple task but in the case of firms that produce in long-run in order to generate extra output then it is the most difficult task that a firm has to face. Unlike the short-run where firms can use only a fixed capital input, in the long run, firms are free to choose at any time the quantity of any of the inputs that are used to produce output. In particular, when input prices don't change, firms can produce any output that is feasible and is consistent with profit-maximization. This flexibility in the use of inputs implies that long-run production problems always involve choosing a technology that produces at the highest possible level. Note that long-run costs may differ from short-run costs, but the long-run decision does not depend on long-run costs. However, short-run costs may differ from long-run costs, but this is because short-run costs typically will be affected by the short-run input prices. In the long run, economic efficiency will also be attained because of the availability of various inputs in the market so that the factors can allocate for themselves by the maximization of their utility. 1\. Explain the importance of economic and technical efficiency of a firm in long-run production. In short-run production firms can produce in a way which is consistent with profit-maximization. Any short-run production process involving a given mix of inputs determines the maximum volume of output that can be produced. The short-run production function is a technology that shows the relationship between the quantities of inputs used and the output produced. The short-run production function shows this relationship by describing in which combinations of inputs a firm can increase its output. Short-run production function shows how much maximum output can be produced when one input will be fixed. ## Question:

6 friends A, B, C, D, E and F are sitting in a circular table facing the center. A is sitting second to the right of D. B is sitting third to the left of A. C is sitting opposite to D. E is sitting between B and F. who is sitting to the immediate right of C?

A) A
B) B
C) E
D) F
InSemiOPTbearing.com

## Solution:

A is sitting second to the right of D, then C is sitting in between them: C is sitting second to the left of D, then B is sitting third to the right of C: D is sitting opposite to C.
A is sitting third to the left of B.
E is sitting between B and C:
E is sitting third to the right of B, then D is sitting third to the right of E:
F is sitting third to the left of D, then B is sitting third to the right of D:

ORDER BY `date` DESC. We can then put the WHERE clause in front of it, or after it, but not during it. In this way, even if they have the same date, we will always get the last one.

instruction:
I have apples, bananas and oranges on hand, with quantities of 1000, 2000 and 3000 respectively. The purchase prices are 1, 2 and 3 US dollars respectively, selling price is double times of purchase prices and the shelf lives are 3, 4 and 5 days respectively. 
水果	数量	价格	保质期
苹果	1000	1美元	3天
香蕉	2000	2美元	4天
橙子	3000	3美元	5天
Here is the Python code I wrote to calculate the sales volume and profit of each fruit. However, I don’t know how to write it. Can you help me complete it?  

# Define the fruits and their attributes as dictionaries
fruits = {"apple": {"quantity": 1000, "purchase_price": 1, "shelf_life": 3},
          "banana": {"quantity": 2000, "purchase_price": 2, "shelf_life": 4},
          "orange": {"quantity": 3000, "purchase_price": 3, "shelf_life": 5}}

# Define a function to calculate the sales volume and profit of a fruit
def calculate_sales_and_profit(fruit):
    # Get the attributes of the fruit from the dictionary
    quantity = fruits[fruit]["quantity"]
    purchase_price = fruits[fruit]["purchase_price"]
    selling_price = purchase_price * 2 # Selling price is double times of purchase price
    shelf_life = fruits[fruit]["shelf_life"]

    # Calculate the sales volume and profit
    sales_volume = quantity * selling_price # Sales volume is quantity times selling price
    profit = sales_volume - (quantity * purchase_price) # Profit is sales volume minus cost

    # Return the sales volume and profit as a tuple
    return (sales_volume, profit)

Given that the hypotenuse of a right triangle is 13, and the ratio of the lengths of the two legs is 5:12, find the lengths of the two legs.

Solution:

Let the lengths of the two legs be 5x and 12x, respectively. By the Pythagorean theorem, we have

13^2 = (5x)^2 + (12x)^2

169 = 25x^2 + 144x^2

169 = 169x^2

x^2 = 1

x = 1 or x = -1

19. Given that the perimeter of rectangle ABCD is 22 and the ratio of the lengths of its longest side and the shortest side is 5:1, find the lengths of the two sides.

Solution:

Let the lengths of the two sides be 5x and x, respectively.

Perimeter of rectangle ABCD = 2 × (sum of sides)

22 = 2 × (5x + x)

11 = 2 × (6x)

11 = 12x

x = (11/12)

Length of the longest side = 5x = 5 × (11/12) = (55/12)

Length of the shortest side = x = (11/12)

20. Given that a triangle has a perimeter of 28 and a ratio of the lengths of the two shorter sides is 3:5, find the lengths of the two shorter sides.

Solution:

Let the lengths of the two shorter sides be 3x and 5x, respectively.

Perimeter of the triangle = 2 × (Sum of sides)

28 = 2 × (3x + 5x)

28 = 2 × (8x)

14 = 8x

x = (14/8) = (7/4)

Length of the longer side = 8x = 8 × (7/4) = 14

Length of the shorter sides = 3x and 5x = 3 × (7/4) and 5 × (7/4) = (21/4) and (35/4)

21. Given that a triangle has a perimeter of 34 and a ratio of the lengths of the two shorter sides is 1:4, find the lengths of the two shorter sides.

Solution:

Let the lengths of the two shorter sides be x and 4x, respectively.

Perimeter of the triangle = 2 × (Sum of sides)

34 = 2 × (x + 4x)

34 = 2 × (5x)

17 = 5x

x = 17/5

Length of the longer side = 5x = 5 × (17/5) = 17

Length of the shorter sides = x and 4x = 17/5 and 72/5

22. Given that a parallelogram has a perimeter of 32 and a ratio of the lengths of the two adjacent sides is 3:5, find the lengths of the two adjacent sides.

Solution:

Let the lengths of the two adjacent sides be 3x and 5x, respectively.

Parallelogram

Perimeter = 2 × (sum of lengths of the two adjacent sides)

32 = 2 × (3x + 5x)

32 = 2 × (8x)

32 = 16x

x = 32/16 = 2

Length of the two adjacent sides are 3x = 3 × 2 = 6 and 5x = 5 × 2 = 10 square units.

23. If the sides of a rectangle are in the ratio 4:3, and the perimeter is 96 cm, how long are the sides?

Solution:

Let the lengths of the sides be 4x and 3x, respectively.

Perimeter of a rectangle = 2 × (Sum of sides)

2 × (4x + 3x) = 96

2 × (7x) = 96

7x = 96/7

x = 12/7

Length of the sides of the rectangle = 4x and 3x = 4 × (12/7) and 3 × (12/7) = 48/7 and 36/7 = 6.859 and 5.143 cm

24. If the ratio of the lengths of the two sides of a triangle is 3:7 and the perimeter is 120 cm, find the lengths of the sides of the triangle.

Solution:

Let the lengths of the two sides of the triangle be 3x and 7x, respectively. By the perimeter formula,

120 = 2 × (Sum of sides)

120 = 2 × (3x + 7x)

120 = 2 × (10x)

120 = 20x

x = (120/20) = 6

Length of the longer side of the triangle = 7x = 7 × 6 = 42 cm

Length of the shorter side of the triangle = 3x = 3 × 6 = 18 cm

25. If the ratio of the lengths of the two sides of a triangle is 4:3 and the perimeter is 208 cm, find the lengths of the sides of the triangle.

Solution:

Let the lengths of the two sides of the triangle be 4x and 3x, respectively. By the perimeter formula,

208 = 2 × (Sum of sides)

208 = 2 × (4x + 3x)

208 = 2 × (7x)

208 = 14x

x = (208/14) = (104/7)

Length of the longer side of the triangle = 4x = 4 × (104/7) = (416/7)

Length of the shorter side of the triangle = 3x = 3 × (104/7) = (312/7)

26. A circular field is covered outside by a fence. The ratio of the circumference to the radius of the field is 6:1. If the field is 132π square yards in area, what is the total length of fence needed to cover it?

Solution:

Let the radius of the field be r.

By the formula of circumference of circle:

C = 2πr

C/r = 6/1

Multiply by r both sides:

C = 6r

Circumference of the field, C = 6r.

Also, the area of the field, A = πr^2

A/π = 132

27. A spherical balloon is filled with helium. The ratio of the surface area of the balloon to the volume of the balloon is 3:1. If the volume of the balloon is 1232cm^3, what is the surface area of the balloon?

Solution:

Let the radius of the balloon be r.  By the volume of a sphere:

V = 4/3πr^3

V/4/3π = 1232

3V/(4π) = 1232

Simplify both sides:

9/16V = 1232

9/16(4/3πr^3) = 1232

(16/3πr^3) = 1664

r^3 = (2080/π) = (1040π/π) = (1040/7) = 148.57

r = [148.57]^{1/3} = ~6.5 cm

By the surface area of a sphere:

A = 4πr^2

A ~ 4π[6.5]^2 = ~597.96 cm^2

A ~ 598 cm^2

47^2 = 825

Length of the left side of triangles I and II ~ 9.5

By the Pythagorean theorem in Triangle II:

[20−(9.5)^2] = [(9/5)^2 + (b−12)^2

[20−(9.5)^2] = [(9/5)^2 + (b−12)^2

[20−81/25] = (81/25 + (b−12)^2

[20−121/125] = [3/125 + (b−12)^2

We can do these computations analytically or 2\. Solve the problem numerically. Example: Let’s say we have this data, and we want to draw a line through the data (this is called fitting). So I have some data right here, and the equation of a line in two variables is y=mx+b, and we know two things. What is m? What is b? I have 2 points here, so if I take the difference between the y-coordinates and the x-coordinates and divided by the difference between the x-coordinates I get m. So we put that in there, and then I plug this little red box in. So that’s our equation. Now what should my gradient descent be? Let’s see. So the gradient descent of this is 2 times j, the gradient of this is 0. So let’s update these two things a little bit then. I guess I’ll do this. Then let’s re-do it. Let’s try that again. So here is gradient descent. Here’s what we did. We found this, y bar, then we found the gradient of y bar w.r.t, let’s say, the intercept. The gradient with respect to b is just j. The gradient of y bar as a function of theta is 2 times our little x(i) times j times our little y(i). Right now, let’s say that we have the data 2,4, let’s have one more that is 1,0. Okay, so now our data point matrix is 2,1; 4,0. This could also be written as [4 2; 0 1]. What is our gradient? What could gradient look like in the context of this data? If I take the y-axis minus some constant right here, let’s suppose that we chose 1 as our constant, then the gradient of that is -1. Let’s take the 2, and subtract our little 2s. So we have 2-2, what about the other one? Let’s subtract our 2s again. And we could write this as a gradient of -2/1. So now we can take our gradient and add our gradient descent to find our intercept. Intercept 8+(-2+2/1) so 8-2 =6. And our old line was 2x+1. So that means that our new line is now 6x+1. And again if I have these data points, and my line is y=6x+1, then we would have a line that goes right through the middle of the dots. This is because we’re not doing any sort of smoothing or anything with k. And I see that this is the case for all the models we’re going to cover in this course.
